description: The conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen led the New York Philharmonic in the fourth installment of the Hungarian Echoes festival at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.
title: Esa-Pekka Salonen and New York Philharmonic
title_page: Esa-Pekka Salonen and New York Philharmonic - Review - The New York Times
maintext:
“Three out of four pieces,” an audience member said to her companion as they made their way up the aisle at Avery Fisher Hall after a concert by the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. “That’s not too bad.”
The program was the fourth and final installment in the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen’s festival with the orchestra, Hungarian Echoes.(The third, really, if you considered one single-evening outing a transitional stopgap.) As in the preceding programs, Mr. Salonen matched works by Bartok (two here) with pieces by Haydn and Ligeti (one each), drawing parallels among imposing masters with Hungarian ties.
This inveterate eavesdropper slowed slightly to learn which piece had failed the listener’s litmus test. But no answer.
